headline.main: Breastfeeding Ads Delayed By a Dispute Over Content

docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Department softens national advertising campaign to promote breastfeeding after complaints from Mead Johnson, division of Bristol-Myers Squibb and Abbott Laboratories that make infant formula; newsletter distributed by Ad Council, nonprofit group developing advertisements for government, says department planned to begin campaign in December; department spokeswoman Christina Pearson says it is not clear when ads will begin; department's Asst Sec Kevin Keane will meet with group of breastfeeding experts who have been working on campaign to discuss changes to ads; original campaign focused on 'risks of associated with not breastfeeding; Dr Joe M Sanders, executive director of American Academy of Pediatrics, has misgivings about ads; Dr Lawrence M Gartner, head of academy's breastfeeding committee, questions source of opposition; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Federal officials have softened a national advertising campaign to promote breastfeeding after complaints from two companies that make infant formula, according to several doctors and nurses who are helping the government with the effort. A newsletter distributed by the Ad Council, a nonprofit group developing the advertisements for the government, said that the Department of Health and Human Services planned to begin the campaign this month. But Christina Pearson, a spokeswoman for the department, said yesterday that it was not clear when the advertisements would begin.

docs.abstract: Fifteen percent of children in US are considered overweight and four new studies on children and heart disease point out importance of preventative measures at early age if heart disease risk factors are apparent; Dr Henry C McGill Jr, Southwest Foundation for Biomedical Research (San Antonio) senior scientist emeritus, holds that life style changes for healthy heart are best made in childhood before unhealthy behavioral patterns are established; Dr Stephen B Hulley, University of California (San Francisco) epidemiology and biostatistics chairman, however, feels too much emphasis on condition that will not likely present itself for 50 years could have negative emotional effects on children; some other experts believe that good overall approach to children's health is best way to impact future health of heart; photos; charts (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: As parents and doctors struggle with an epidemic of childhood obesity in America, Anne Youngquist worries about a subtler menace that may not threaten her three children for decades: heart disease. About eight years ago, after learning that her husband, Rod, suffered from elevated cholesterol, she started having their children's cholesterol checked, too. Bryce, at 16 their oldest child, went on a low dose of cholesterol-lowering statin drugs three years ago. Alyssa, 14, has also gone on statins. Eight-year-old Brady is not on medication, but he, too, joins the family in a diet low in fat; to the Youngquists 2 percent milk tastes like heavy cream.
